text: The drunk’s footsteps draw closer and closer, the cups on the table trembling lightly as the smell of alcohol thickens in the air.
I do not step back. Instead, I slowly rest my hand on the hilt of my short sword, my fingertips pressing down slightly.
“You’d better stop.”
The drunk pauses for a moment, the corner of his mouth twitching. He doesn’t seem to take me seriously and steps forward again.
A flash of steel—my blade is already drawn. The chill edge brushes across his throat, leaving a thin pale line where the skin meets the sword.
His breath catches. He freezes completely, not even daring to move his eyes.
“Move again, and I’ll call the town guard.”
The drunk swallows with difficulty, his neck trembling slightly beneath the blade.
“You… you’re joking, right?”
I do not answer. I simply press the blade an inch closer, the cold gleam reflecting on his face as if even his sweat has frozen.
The only sounds in the air are the crackle of the fire and his ragged breathing.
Alicia stands to the side, watching me calmly. A trace of approval flickers in her eyes.
“Stand down.”
The drunk stumbles backward, nearly crawling as he rushes out the door, crashing into the wind and snow.
With a loud bang, the door is slammed shut by the wind, and the hearth flame wavers slightly.
I withdraw my short sword. The blade glints faintly in the firelight, like a bolt of lightning frozen in place.
“Well done.”
“I just reacted quickly by chance.”
She looks at me as if she wants to say something, but only offers a faint smile.
“Don’t get used to relying on luck.”
She turns and glances over the overturned tables and spilled wine.
“Clean this up. I’ll help you.”
Her tone remains calm, though softer than before.
“Alright.”
She removes the silver ring from her finger and lightly tosses it to me.
“You reacted well. Take this—perhaps it’ll help you if something like this happens again.”
Intricate circuits are engraved along the inner side of the ring, faintly glowing blue.
I lower my sword and pick up the ring, walking toward the counter. The hearth begins to dance again, and the chill in the air gradually fades.
